I also did a little experiment with the unread counts on the left side but I wasn't as convinced with that. Showing it here in any case for transparency.
Screen-Shot-2018-08-22-at-1.31.31-PM.png
I like the elimination of the gray background in favor of a thin border. I'm -0.1 on the colored border. I like the color cue, but I fear we already have too much color going on in the sidebar.

If we feel that the colors are too distracting or take away too much attention, we could also try the following styling which I feel is more modern and doesn't appear as blobs of gray which come across as being unstyled. I believe these attract less attention than the gray blobs we have currently, but I'm not actually sure that this is necessarily a bad thing. ( Would take current users a slight adjustment in what to look for in case of unreads but I think that adjustment would be pretty quick and easy ).
Screen-Shot-2018-08-23-at-9.22.22-AM.png

A couple more images here for context and side-by-side comparison.
Screen-Shot-2018-08-23-at-9.26.59-AM.png Screen-Shot-2018-08-23-at-9.27.09-AM.png
I like the grey border + bold number!

Awesome :slight_smile:

How could we go about getting this change into master? Should i create a PR? Is it likely to be merged?

@Armaan Ahluwalia if you update a PR with that change, we can try test-deploying it here and see what people think. Wouldn't merge until a while after trying it here to get reactions, since it'd a very high-visibility change.

I like the thin border over the gray background; it's more consistent with the rest of the UI. I think it's better that the borders are colored; I don't think the colored borders add noise; they help to strengthen the association between a stream and that stream's designated color.

Hi all. I've put in a PR for a couple of changes. Please do take a look and let me know if it passes muster :slight_smile:
I would be quite excited to see these changes on this realm. React if you agree. #10502
I like the new design :)
I don't like it and I think it is a regression over what we have.
I don't think it looks better than what we have now (very subjective)
But also objectively I don't think it looks like 'unread count' UI element that is established as 'solid background, rounded, with a number on it'.
Proof: unread counts/badges default OS ones on Android and iOS, and also on the majority of apps (googling for 'unread counts' is a good random-ish sample)

I like the new design visually, but I'm swayed by the argument that @Boris Yankov is making. It seems like a pretty strong convention to use a dark background. And I'm wary to change these unless it's a pretty clear win. (I know we'll have some detractors for basically any UI change, but I'm actually fine with the status quo here.)

Here's an image search for unread counts:

https://www.google.com/search?q=unread+counts&client=firefox-b-1-ab&source=lnms&tbm=isch&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwiirPHa1rXdAhUOON8KHXJlDpEQ_AUICigB&biw=1218&bih=573

I don't like it and I think it is a regression over what we have.

Same here. I can't imagine having a transparent background in the unread counts.

I think it's better that the borders are colored; I don't think the colored borders add noise;

IMO, it definitely adds the noise, the left-sidebar will be like a rainbow.
Personally, I like the current design of the unread counts though we could play with the font-size/font-weight to make it better.
I think unread count in badges is different from unread count in this context. The current unread counts are pretty heavy, when you have a lot of them. So I'm still pro trying out that change.

Although I do hear what all of you are saying, I think I have to preface these changes with a few points -

1) From a design perspective, I felt - both when I first started using zulip, as well as when I review the design - the unread counts have too much impact in the visual hierarchy. They need to be toned down and I feel the new design achieves this.

2) Unread counts here in zulip are less akin to the images @Steve Howell presented and more like something you might find in your email inbox ( See attached image ). This is because we are not funneling all notifications into one "count" rather these are more an aggregation of unread messages in different parts of the application. Therefore I don't feel they need to stick to unread count styling seen on app badges as referenced by some of you.

3) I feel perhaps there might be an element of resistance to change at work here. I firmly believe in the design philosophy of experimentation and specially when it comes to design too much theorizing and not enough experimentation leads to stagnation. Couldn't we just give it a shot on the realm and take a poll at the end of some time period?
Screen-Shot-2018-09-12-at-9.03.39-PM.png
I'm definitely up for experimentation here--I didn't mean to sound too negative.
Not at all. I hope I don‚Äôt sound defensive. Merely trying to be convincing
I am definitely in favor of what Gmail is doing, no circles whatsover in that case!

I second the whole Gmail style.
Not much of a fan of the current styling.
I prefer the design by @Armaan Ahluwalia to the current one, but the Gmail style to both. Think it would be better though to offer a choice. Similar to the way you can customise the sidebar colours on Slack.
I'd certainly be on board for trying it out on this server for a day and seeing how it feels.

In the interest of transparency -- I just tested styling the unread counts without the border and I'm not particularly satisfied with the results.

I feel the border attaches more meaning to the counts without disrupting the visual hierarchy of the page. Attaching a screenshot of test.
Screen-Shot-2018-09-13-at-5.15.37-PM.png
I do think however, that both those alternatives are an improvement over the current styling so I would love to see either of them tested here :slight_smile:
I prefer the one with border over this as well.

I think this is an improvement over the borders. I don't think the border was adding any meaning, considering it is very different from the 'badges' styling. Badges are solid and usually circular, while this is just a border with some border-radius (less than circular)

I think it's better that the borders are colored; I don't think the colored borders add noise;

IMO, it definitely adds the noise, the left-sidebar will be like a rainbow.

The left sidebar would certainly look more colorful; that is, the amount of color the design uses would increase, and I don't think that's necessarily lessening the usability of the design. It just means that what's being communicated - in this case, visually - is more specific. In a similar sense, a verbal statement can discuss something very specific or generalized, but that's unrelated to how true the statement is.

Colors can be a source of visual noise, but I would argue that this isn't the case for colored borders because they aren't adding any new colors that aren't already part of Zulip's design.

I agree with @Jack Zhang here. Having colors for the icons that are to the left of the stream names in the sidebar is kinda pointless if we don't reinforce the color theme elsewhere.(I guess it's true that even those colors in complete isolation are vaguely useful to help you quickly scan a list, to the extent that your visual brain registers the colors.)

Right now we reinforce the colors mostly with the recipient bars. I'm not sure how much value adding color to the unread counts would have, since you already have them on the same line as the stream names.
It's worth doing a quick poll (knowing that we'll also try out least a couple of these options here). For unread counts do you prefer...
/poll

I also think that badges are pretty contextually different from Zulip unreads. A badge's count is usually related to a number of things other than new messages - promotions, reminders, updates - and it can be used for whatever a developer decides. The unread counts refer to only unread Zulip messages, which is a lot more specific, so I don't think we have to closely adhere to that convention in this case.

Some additional thoughts from me - I have previously ( before submitting the original design ) tried out colours for unread counts and found it added way too much noise as opposed to signal. I came upon the gray with borders as a reduced solution and without borders is a further reduction on that solution. Personally I like tending towards the least possible required to convey something since these kinds of visual cues pile up as things get mixed and added.

That being said I‚Äôd like for some final weigh in from @Rishi Gupta or go for the poll so we know what to merge in as a trial and make it easier for Tim.
